email.title: Weekly Digest

image.title: Did you know: The term 'Digest' comes from the word 'Digestives' relating to the biscuits we put at the at start of every email!

email.text:
Hi everyone,
After a long weekend of co-running IC HealthHack 2020, we are saying farewell to our Hackathon February. We hope everyone who attended HealthHack (and all other hackathons we ran this month) enjoyed themselves and hopefully learned something useful and practical.
Speaking of learning, we are in the final weeks of our Python and Raspberry Pi workshops. Certainly a successful term for DoCSoc Education, we hope that you found the courses useful (and we would love to hear feedback!).
Next week, we will be holding Revel - our annual black-tie event! One last party before we all settle down into the exam season, Revel will not disappoint, being held in Quaglino's this year and also featuring the popular DJ Antics! Prepare your fancy outfits and bring your party attitude this Monday!
More notices to follow below!
email.heading: The Hello World Hack: Looking for volunteers!
email.text:
Want to improve your leadership and communication skills by helping to run coding activities and talks that will inspire the next generation of young women?
Hello World Hack is a hackathon hosted by Imperial’s Computing and Maths Departments that aims to introduce girls in Years 3 to 5 (ages 7-10) to computer science and show them what can be achieved by learning to code!
We’re looking for female volunteers from any STEM discipline to help host this EXCITING and INTERACTIVE event on Tuesday 24th March 2020
**If you would like to get involved or find out more, please email Dr Jackie Bell (Jaclyn.bell@imperial.ac.uk) by 5pm on Thursday 12th March 2020**
_See attached PDF for more information._
email.heading: Roaring Revel

event.text:
**This event is for 18+ only.**
A little party never killed nobody, so join RCSU and DoCSoc for an extravagant night of glitz, glam and a party fit for the 20's - here's to Roaring Revel!
From Spanish rooftop bars to Parisian themed halls, we're now taking you back in time to the Prohibition era. Our chosen gin mill, Quaglino's, is decorated to the taste of the period and has a history as rich as the location of St James's.
The evening will start with a cocktail reception with further drinks served later as the night progresses. We will also be serving canapés and providing entertainment throughout the evening. So wear your ritziest garms and get ready to party like it's the 20's!

email.heading: DoCSoc goes to Ballie Ballerson

event.text:
Take a break from all the deadlines and revision and come have some fun with DoCSoc at Ballie Ballerson Soho!!
DoCSoc will be heavily subsidising tickets to just £6.00! We only have a limited number of tickets for this event, so make sure to try and get one.
Each ticket include a welcome prosecco drink, a cocktail, a whole pizza and 3 hours access to the ball pits at Ballie Ballerson Soho! We will meet outside the venue at 6:30.
We hope to see you there!
-------------------------------------------------------------- You must be a member of DoCSoc by Tuesday 25th November in order to be admitted. Computing, JMC, and EIE students are automatically members of DoCSoc. Membership is £30.
Find out more: http://docsoc.co.uk/join

email.heading: DoCSoc: Meet the Candidates!

event.text:
Committee nominations have closed on Friday 28th February and now it's time to Meet the Candidates!
Join us in Huxley 311 from 1pm on Thursday 5th March to meet the candidates running for all of the positions in DoCSoc.
This is your chance to ask any questions you may have, and hear more about what each candidate is campaigning for! Candidates for DoCSoc and Dep Reps will all be present.
Candidates for contested positions: Please turn up and prepare a 1 minute speech on why you think you'd be good for the position. After each pitch, up to 2 questions will be asked from the audience.

email.heading: Women in Gaming Panel

event.text:
We would like to invite you to the women in gaming panel, where we will try to increase the visibility and representation of women in gaming.
The panel will be an hour long, including a 10-15 min Q&A with the panelists, followed by an informal networking session with a catered reception.
The panel will take place on Tuesday 10th March at 6:30pm in Blackett LT1, located on Imperial's South Kensington Campus.
This event is part of Women's History Month at Imperial College London and is open to everyone! Just make sure to grab a ticket on Eventbrite to ensure you have food at the event! Let us know about any dietary requirements by emailing us at docsoc@ic.ac.uk.

email.heading: International Women's Day Conference 2020

event.text:
In honour of International Women’s Day, WiC are excited to announce a half-day conference at Imperial College London on the 11th of March. Join us to hear from STEM leaders across industry and academia about their career journeys followed by a panel on how discrimination can be tackled to make the tech industry a more welcoming place for minorities. Open to all! Graduate students are also invited to a CV+Interview lunchtime workshop run by Faculty.ai in room 218. Workshop is aimed at those preparing the transition from academia to industry and/or consulting.
Confirmed speakers: Katerina Daminova, Business Strategy at Yobota Professor Nigar Hashimzade, Director of Research, Department of Economics and Finance, Brunel Professor Julie McCann, Head of Adaptive Emergent Systems Engineering (AESE) group, Imperial Becky Plummer, Team Leader, Software Infrastructure, Bloomberg Sepi Chakaveh, CEO/Founder of Pixsellar Christina Franzeskides, COO of Comind

email.heading: TheDataOpen - Citadel Spring Datathon
email.sponsor:
**Explore. Build. Win.**
The Data Open brings together the best minds in mathematics, engineering, science, and technology to collaborate and compete using the world’s most important data sets.
[Sign Up Now - Limited spots available!](http://thedataopen.com/)
You can win $25000 in cash prizes and the winning team gains an automatic entry into the final Data Open competition.
_Check out the attached PDF for more information._
email.heading: WiTT at Jane Street
email.sponsor:
\ **We are excited to host our sixth year of WiTT at Jane Street! Will you be there?**
Women in Trading and Technology (WiTT) is a three-day programme designed for women in their penultimate year of university as of autumn 2020. Participants will have an exclusive opportunity to explore careers within our firm and attend one of two educational programmes: quantitative trading and software engineering.
Both programmes feature interactive classes and activities during the day, and evening social events to speak with Jane Street employees and other women attending the event in a more casual setting.
The quantitative trading programme focuses on mathematical and financial topics—such as probability, market structure, and arbitrage—through a combination of short classroom lectures, group games, and mock trading sessions. There is a curriculum of core subjects with flexibility to explore alternative areas of interest, and plenty of opportunities for close interaction with our traders.
The software engineering programme focuses on the fundamentals of building electronic trading systems, OCaml, and the library and tools we use in our everyday work at Jane Street. Participants will put these tools to use by writing the back end and UI for a computer game, along with a program that trades on a simulated stock exchange. These activities involve a combination of classroom lectures, group games and exercises, and one-on-one mentorship.
Selected students will arrive in London on the evening of Sunday, 20 September and will depart the evening of Wednesday, 23 September. Jane Street will provide all travel to and from London, accommodation at a hotel near the office, and of course, plenty of food and drinks throughout the event.
Jane Street is a quantitative trading firm that uses innovative technology, a scientific approach, and a deep understanding of markets to guide our business. Founded in 2000, Jane Street employs more than 1,100 people with offices in New York, London, Amsterdam, and Hong Kong. We are always on the lookout for great new people to join our team.
The environment at Jane Street is open, informal, intellectual, and fun. The dress code is casual, the kitchen is stocked, and discussions are always lively. Teaching and learning are central activities through classes, mentoring, and discussion.
Selected students will arrive in London on the evening of Sunday, 20 September and will depart the evening of Wednesday, 23 September. Jane Street will provide all travel to and from London, accommodation at a hotel near the office, and of course, plenty of food and drinks throughout the event.
**Apply here: https://janestreet.com/apply-witt**
**Who: Women in their second year of study in Autumn 2020\ When: 20th - 23rd September 2020\ Deadline to apply: Sunday, 5th July 2020 at 11.59pm BST**
